monogr.title: Commentaries of that diuine Iohn Caluine, vpon the prophet Daniell, translated into Englishe, especially for the vse of the family of the ryght honorable Earle of Huntingdon, to set forth as in a glasse, how one may profitably read the Scriptures, by consideryng the text, meditatyng the sense therof, and by prayer
monogr.author: Calvin, Jean

div.head: ¶ To the Reader.
div.p:
GOod Reader, blame not this thyng I besech thee, which I haue done in this plaine and rude sort, for the commoditie of the simple and vnlearned: whom I did thinke vnable to comprehende in theyr myndes, and to apply vnto their consciences these learned Cōmentaries of this diuine Caluine, vnles they were somethyng abbridged and ye expositions of the Hebrue wordes, which would haue bene somethyng darke in our lāguage, omitted. Wherfore, as I do professe my selfe to bee one of his scholers, and do prayse God for the same more then for any earthly matter: so do I not of arrogancie alter or chaunge any thing in his writynges. But because I do know right well that if he were alyue hym selfe, he would suffer all his doings to be applyed to the commoditie of the Church: therfore now whē I do offer his trauayles to the vnlearned of our English nation, who are desirous of the same, I do so present them as may be most comfortable to their conscience, and least tedious to such simple persons as are not able to comprehend all his
large and learned discourses. And this abbrydgement do I make but in the two first Chapters and in few places besides: puttyng into print at this present, the one halfe of the booke of Daniell, conteynyng the first vj. Chapiters, which do treate of the particular hystories wrought by God in hys tyme, and therfore semeth vnto me farre diuerse from the latter vj. Chapters: wherin he prophecieth of all thynges that should come vnto the elect people vntill the commyng of Messias, and toucheth also some thynges that be generall vnto all, euen to the end of the world. The which latter part also I do meane (by Gods grace) to publish for the instruction of our nation in these obscure Prophecies, if I can perceaue this former trauayle to be well accepted of the godly, which is my desire, and whom I do exhorte in the Lord, to read the Scriptures attentyuely, to meditate the same diligently, to pray continually.
